intro: Agapetes lacei var. tomentella, commonly known as the woolly agapete, is a species of flowering plant in the Ericaceae family. It is native to the high-altitude regions of South America, particularly in the Andes. The plant is characterized by its dense, woolly foliage that covers its stems and leaves, giving it a distinctive appearance. It typically grows in shaded, moist environments, often found in cloud forests. The flowers are small and clustered, producing a fragrant aroma that attracts pollinators such as bees and moths.
